tit.cmt: 以下「社倉」と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 義倉（ぎそう）とは、災害や飢饉に備えて米などの穀物を一般より徴収し、または富者から寄付を得て、これを貯蓄するために国内の要地に設けた倉庫。
sen.e: Giso was a warehouse which was constructed in domestic important places to store rice and other grain in case of natural disasters and famine, and the grain in stock was one which was collected from ordinary people or acquired using the cash contributions by the rich.

sen.j: 万一に備える一方で穀物の腐敗の防止と義倉の維持のために古い穀物を安価で売却（出糶）し、また一般に低利で貸し付ける（借放）事も行われていた。
sen.e: While storing them for emergencies, cereal crops long stored in a giso warehouse were sold (deseri (出糶, to be on sale)) at a reasonable price or loaned (shakuho (借放.定訳不明)) at a low interest rate to prevent the grain from deteriorating and maintain giso warehouses.

sen.e: In China, Shito zokunin jo in "Rites of Zhou" talks about its origin that Zhou applied 'Isekiho (委積法.定訳不明)', and according the definition Sonhei CHO, Takushi shosho (account office) made in the Sui Dynasty Kaiko eight (585), that was obvious on record, people from the domains to ordinary people were forced to provide a certain amount of awa or kibi millets and those millets were stored in giso warehouses which were constructed in prefectures.
